0.text: TOM SCOTT: Our civilisation relies on these.

3.text:
This is a shipping container. 8 feet, by 8
feet, by 20 feet, made of steel and plywood.

7.text: And they are everywhere. On every continent.

10.text:
Almost everywhere that there are humans, there
are shipping containers.

13.text:
They’re used as storage, as shops, as homes,
even an Antarctic base.

17.text:
But most importantly: they’re used for moving
stuff.

20.text:
Before shipping containers were invented,
everything transported by ship would be a

24.text: different size and in a different package.

27.text:
And it’d take a week to load and unload
even a small cargo ship.

31.text:
But now: almost everything goes by container,
and the ships are loaded by giant cranes.

36.text:
Like these, the largest in the world, at London
Gateway.

39.text:
JAMES RAY: Below us we have got the Cap San
Marco. It’s a 300m long vessel.

44.text:
We’ve currently got four gantry cranes working
on it; it should be here for roughly 12 hours.

50.text:
TOM: And in that twelve hours, you move how
many containers?

53.text:
JAMES: Approximately we’ll be moving just
over 1100 containers, both discharge and load.

60.text:
There is a worldwide network of containers
and ports. It’s like an internet for physical things.

66.text:
In the same way that standardising on the
internet meant that

69.text:
all computers could talk to each other, standardising
on the shipping container

73.text:
meant that all the ports, worldwide, could
just send stuff to each other.

77.text:
COSMIN CARSTEA: You see a container has just
been brought to our post,

81.text: and now is going all the way, full speed.

86.text:
TOM: And so that’s basically just an enormous
robot.

89.text:
COSMIN: Yeah. It is 200 tonnes of robot. It
takes it, it puts it in the stack.

95.text:
It’s a temporary storage area for the containers.
A big 3D puzzle.

100.text:
From the stack to the vessel, we have equipment
called “shuttle”.

102.text:
It’s a very powerful, very fast machine
that has lifting capability,

107.text: as well as useful horizontal transfer.

110.text:
It’s like a truck and a crane at the same
time.

113.text:
And from there, our 2,000 tonne quay cranes
will take it, like a snowflake,

118.text:
and put it in the right location, safely on
the vessel.

121.text:
TOM: Let’s say you’re in China, selling
10,000 widgets to a supermarket in the UK.

125.text:
You don’t have to worry about how they’re
going to get there,

128.text:
you just put them in a container, you take
it to a port, and it vanished into the system.

133.text:
And barring disaster, a few days later after
it’s been routed on ships,

136.text:
and through transhipping ports, essentially
routers: it arrives at its destination port.

141.text:
At the port, the container is loaded onto
a truck or a train.

145.text:
Because the containers are all standardized,
every mode of transport can just accept them.

149.text:
And then it’s taken off to the supermarket’s
distribution centre,

152.text:
where it’s emptied, and the contents sent
off to individual shops.

155.text:
Increasingly, the supermarkets are doing that
here, because, well,

157.text:
why have a distribution centre and that extra
journey when you can just do it at the port?

163.text:
Here’s the important point: it doesn’t
matter what’s in the container.

167.text:
It’s just a box that fits into the patterns
of literally millions of other boxes

173.text:
that are moving around the globe at any point
in time.

176.text:
Unless there’s dangerous cargo, not even
the crew on the ship know about the contents.

181.text:
Whisky was one of the first things sent by
container.

184.text:
There used to be a lot of accidental breakages
of whisky, I can’t imagine why, but suddenly,

189.text:
they magically stopped once the bottles were
inside a sealed metal box.

194.text:
Heck, someone once tried to send himself halfway
round the world by container,

200.text:
The vast majority of things that are made
in one country, and sold in another country,

207.text:
World trade relies of this network of physical
things just as much as it does the internet.

213.text:
Our civilisation really does hold together
because of these metal boxes and these giant cranes.
